Title: Great place for hard workers!
Pro: You work for human beings that you actually see and talk to. The partners are experts in their fields that genuinely care about their clients and their employees.

Title: Summer Assitant
Pro:
Colleagues are very willing to help you with any difficulties
Team bonding activities are very common within the organisation, enabled me to easily make friends and bond with my teammates
Con:
Quite local culture, I feel like international people would find it hard to adapt to the culture. 
Overtime hours is common, and everyone does it without complaining, so just do it.

Title: Credit Analyst
Pro: Entry level work with coaching and training, do due diligence, analyzing company's background information , you can do well in the projects
Con: work without many challenges or changes, not many interactions among divisions, probably could involve more advanced analytical tools

Pro:
- Management was very good and they truly care about their employees

- Ability to work on actually relevant work
Con:
- Work life balance: Some days you are at the office all nights when you have a big assignment due 
- There is not a lot of warning before you get a big project

Title: Forward Thinking

Title: Perfect
Pro: Good environment Everything is perfect
Con: Bank less live more .

Title: Lots of opportunities to grow
Pro: In last 4-5 years, there has been a lot of push on experimenting and openness to adopt new technologies. It has become easier to expand roles and find career growth internally if you dare and challenge yourself. Other big organisations and even tech companies have happily taken folks from dbs now, even within my own group due to this experience and have done well.
Con: Couple of tech towers are still very dominated at top so be careful which one you join.

Title: All about DBS within a year experience
Pro: 1. Work life balance 2. Employee perks 3. Career growth related technologies 4. Awesome office timings(8:30am to 5:30pm)—> less traffic 5. Office transportation 6. Great rapo with colleagues and higher officials, very easy to approach people and share thoughts 7. Awesome place for women employees 8. Respect to ideas and suggestions
Con: 1. More equity of gender (require equal ratios of both genders)

Title: People Oriented
Pro: Through out my stay in DBS, I have had a very good experience. DBS is very people oriented. I would always have an opportunity to hear and experience what they are planning and executing in order to always support their people in all aspects of work.
Con: I have no comment in this aspect.

Title: Love working here
Pro: I feel really valued as employee. They have good trainings, benefits, and development programs.
Con: The transparency of salary range per level. Seems the gap is quite big.

Title: Best benefits
Pro: Staff benefits outweigh any other perks of the job. 24 AL, 6 day family care leave for parents, insurance coverage for spouse and child, SUPERB HOME LOAN interest rates (staff rates) etc etc
Con: Mincromangement, contradictory management policies, people who manage the organisation at the top level hardly had done the ground work up (very powerfully connected circles of people) , ZERO work life balance, sales driven (zero empathy for customers), fictions portrayal of “Live More Bank Less”

Title: Don't Join If you want Process, Horizontal /Team Culture
Pro: Good Salary, Leaves. Good benefits You can take risk for money but don't expect process and culture at least at ITT department
Con: Worked with ITT, Forget Analysis there wont be proper Requirement Gathering . Things keep on changing and brings lot of uncertainty. Poor quality code and practices is very prevalent. One side communication from Singapore, no feedback or suggestions considered from INDIA, Hyderabad. They expect only Yes and Understand words Toxic Culture ( Some of the guys who are with DBS for sometime are behaving the same as Singapore Folks) - very insecure to share knowledge and responsibilities . They create a unnecessary hierarchy with in teams My Voice Survey which impacts Manager hike is a sham Totally rigged and you will be called out if your feedback is not in favour of them . BTW it should be Anonymous They compare on par to Google, Amazon etc but not even close to most of the service based Final word : Join this if you are ok to face politics and toxic culture If you had a good experience with US, UK the big MNC culture then SG culture is a big NO

Title: hello

Title: Do NOT apply for the CSO position

Con:
- ZERO worklife balance

- Constantly having to deal with expectations of KPIs to meet, being given ONLY 15 MINUTES a day of personal time to go to the toilet aside from 15 minutes paid break, rest of the time you are expected to take no less than 5 min

Title: More than meets the eye, largely in a good way
Pro: Working in Human Resources, I have a good view of what DBS seeks to do for employees. The awareness of diverse employee needs at different life stages and hence, policies becoming more flexible and equitable is encouraging to see. Grateful for a good culture nurtured by my team leader who cultivates psychological safety, and encourages our learning and growth. I also believe that DBS is going in the right direction bringing together staff with different expertise to collaborate and manage customer journeys from a holistic view instead of working in silos. The work is purposeful and the longer I've been here, the more I feel that DBS has good values, is sincere about social impact, and is building for a sustainable future.
Con:
As a large organisation, DBS inevitably has many processes and systems to navigate. To the bank's credit, there are many guides that have been written up to help staff navigate these and chatbots to assist, but sometimes it can still be hard to find an answer independently. Will need to count on colleagues 
to take time to help andd teach.

Title: DBS India Pros & Cons
Pro:
1) You can expect the real 'Work Life Balance" thing
2) Good and professional environment
3) Opportunity to shape up your career in your area of interest through Internal posting
4) Additional perks are also competitive such as additional credit towards lifestyle related expenses.
Con:
1) Annual appraisals are not competitive at all and you may have to rethink of your decision to associate yourself with this organization.
2) You may find it difficult to plan your working hours, being flexi work culture
3) Indian senior management has to follow the Singapore management always, which slows down the deliverables a lot.

Title: Micromanagers
Pro: Leave benefits are acceptable, time given to learn
Con: Micromanagers around controlling your working hours(clock in and clock out), working in office days although the advertised promise was WFH up to 40% without any concrete reasons provided other than just this is not acceptable. Appearing in office apparently is more important than getting the job done. Mental health importance is promoted but not prioritized.

Title: Great at technology, poor leadership doing ugly politics in Hyderabad
Pro: Great technologies, exciting work, good benefits, amazing learning opportunities
Con: Some Platforms in Hyd are lead by leaders (SVPs) who do bad politics. This is the primary reason for me leaving DBS.

Title: Worst company to work with DBS DAH2 [DO NOT JOIN]
Pro:
Cool office space, other than that nothing.
Great support in times of COVID19.
Con:
No work life balance, will end being in soup between IND and SG leadership tussle which will result in more that 14~15 hrs of work on weekdays and deployments on weekends.

No support for any issue can be expected by manager, hands will be tied by SG leadership.

No proper way of explaining requirement, BA part of Fixed income domain related Project can't even speak proper English and if fail to understand that and implementation for that is missed, then manager or lead will put this mistake on.

Because of this toxic culture, wont find time to learn something new or experiment with latest tech, as there is no SDLC culture here.

If some development needs to be done, tech leads only care about by when it can be done. rather than discussing about design or best coding practices which can be used for the development, diminishing any aspirations of software development.

They compare themselves with Google, Apple, Netflix, Facebook etc... there "GANDALF" model, but failing miserably to bring single value from GANDALF mentioned companies.

Title: More like a Tech company, but still with rooms for improvement
Pro:
Good culture from what I experience around me and what I see from the leadership team. Indeed becoming more and more like a Tech company, less like a traditional bank.
DBS is constantly changing and disrupting itself to catch up with the fast changing world, and DBS encourages a disruptive mindset within its people. So be ready for embrace changes.
Lots of personal development opportunities and programs, and the leadership is very supportive of that.
Con: DBS is a big and complex organisation with many stakeholders to manage. Things does not move as fast as you would like it to be due to various constraints, e.g. resource, money, other high-priority projects, etc.

Title: Company Review
Pro: Stable Job with good bonus ranging for 2-5months for junior employees (AVP and below) and up to 3.5months for senior employees (VP). Bonus highly dependent on your pay, higher your pay lower bonus in terms of months. Good for retirement when pay does not really matter
Con:
1. Not recommended for junior employees as junior employees (AVP & below) need to take on additional projects to promote while senior employees (VP) need not.
2. Very low increment (2% for non promotion years when salary is 6-7k and 4-7% for promotion) due to low benchmark set for ranks but is compensated for high bonus.
3. Any cash given out or off cycle adjustments will be taken into account in next year's bonus/increment. (i.e. No increment in 2021 due to less than ideal business performance, but was subsequently given a mid year adjustment due to business recovering. Mentioned was due to no increment during bonus earlier in the year. However, in 2022 bonus and increment cycle, mentioned that mid year adjustment was given resulting in lower/no increments.
4. Part of bonus paid out in shares which will be paid on the 3rd/4th/5th year from when the shares were issued. Part of the company's tactic as career hostage as these are given out to good performers, knowing that people junior employees might leave for better increments.
5. Management seem to emphasize on employee survey but takes ages to even try to improve. Most improvements are reactive measures.
6. Long hours
7. Generally more concern with senior employees than junior (VPs vs AVP and below)

Title: Weak Middle Management
Pro: Great learning opportunities and a good place to start your first career.
Con:
Due to the internal transfer practice, it is a common sight that it produces weak middle management who aren't trained in the role that they transferred to, but their ego is too high to listen to feedback from "inexperience" fresh graduates and developers who "don't know anything" about the "business".

Many incompetent product owners and project managers resulted in endless and meaningless tech discussions that often go (something) like this...

Middle Management: "Can you draw a pair of lines that are parallel to each other? Oh! By the way, make them perpendicular too!"

Developers: "Ermmm... a pair of lines can't be parallel and perpendicular at the same time."

Middle Management: "Oh come on! You haven't even tried it!"

Developers: "Is just not possible... 🤦‍♂️ You know what? I'll give it a try and get back to you."

Title: Weak Middle Management
Pro: Great learning opportunities and a good place to start your first career.
Con:
Due to the internal transfer practice, it is a common sight that it produces weak middle management who aren't trained in the role that they transferred to, but their ego is too high to listen to feedback from "inexperience" fresh graduates and developers who "don't know anything" about the "business".

Many incompetent product owners and project managers resulted in endless and meaningless tech discussions that often go (something) like this...

Middle Management: "Can you draw a pair of lines that are parallel to each other? Oh! By the way, make them perpendicular too!"

Developers: "Ermmm... a pair of lines can't be parallel and perpendicular at the same time."

Middle Management: "Oh come on! You haven't even tried it!"

Developers: "Is just not possible... 🤦‍♂️ You know what? I'll give it a try and get back to you."

Title: Toxic company - Stay away at all costs
Pro:
1. Benifits like leaves, cab facility.
2. Support during COVID like extra leaves for the employees.
Con:
1. Very Toxic work culture. This is the SIngapore working style. If you have never worked with Singapore companies before and always worked for US/Europe companies in your past, avoid DBS at all costs. You can't fit in well and will start looking outside within 4 months.
2. Pushing the employees to come back to office at any costs.
3. No proper Software Development life cycle. You as a developer is responsible for architecture, design, code, test and deploy. If you are hard worker, the entire work will be on you.
4. Business don't understand the technicals and they don't care about the time it takes to complete the tasks. They simply demand the developers to complete in fixed time and we are bound to complete without any other option.
5. Culture is broken. Most of us won't fit in.
6. People are leaving like crazy because of all these issues. Think thrice before joining.

Follow the right boss and you’ll be rewarded. Which may be actually be a con.

Title: Bad Culture, Double Standard
Pro:
Good for resume
Decent pay
Good mobile app
Con:
Lots of useless meetings, which are just status updates
- eg many daily standups in a day to update teams' status, sprint planning meetings use to update projects' status (read waterfall)
Too many useless meetings till people can't be bothered response to your meeting invites - you have to ping them to ask them if they are attending
Many last minute meeting invites with some that are past your official work hours
Very bad meeting culture/etiquette
Lack of transparency and trust
Old school thinking/mindset
- fear/fomo mindset
- doing extra/double work "just in case" something goes wrong
- many have been with the company for many years and reluctant to change, would say things like "in my time here, i have never encounter this". Bro, time has change, please change your mentality.
Huge benefits difference between perm and contract staff (and the bank relies on lots of contract staff)
- 14 days AL vs minimum 25 ALs
- no $500 flexi benefits (which would help offset utilities bills during WFH)
- no access to 360 feedback (can't get feedback to improve and can't give feedback to your bosses)
- no performance bonus
- these are some to name

Title: Good leaders are hard to find or eroded by the system
Pro: Good benefits, supportive peers, a good internal network for skill upgrading and lots of programmes to engage employees.
Con:
Terrible work-life balance.
The manager leading the team is super lost, nickname "lost lamb", has no clue what is going on, often wasting everyone's time on meaningless endeavours that has no value.
KPI and numbers fall from the sky, no real justification anywhere. 
This manager is terribly unequipped to lead, miscommunication and misdirection rampant, zero to negative value addition. Don't know who assigned him as manager, the PhD like for show only, data related question also don't know. Epic and speechless...
Worst is the ethics: distorting facts, inflating results, sabotaging and scapegoating behaviour, mostly to tear others down and exalt. 
No wonder no one wants to work in banks, and not surprise that my team has 7-8 resignations in 2021 alone, ever since this manager took over in 2020. The number will most probably increase. Yet this manager claims its "bumpy period", so bumpy that new joiners after 1 month resign. Nobody wants to work in this team, does not resonate with DBS PRIDE values at all. GG

Title: Mistake one would never want to do
Pro:
- DBS offers a high package for attracting people initially
- Good market value in the market but no hikes for the employee.
- I am happy to be working under a green field project where I got to learn otherwise it's mostly maintenance of the system.
Con:
People start to leave DBS within the year after they join. Company fails to retain them.
Many reasons for doing so:
- No future planning and goals for the work carried on.
- No sufficient hikes and bonuses
- Non-stop working and continuous pressure from heads
- Managers are inefficient and are self-obsessed
- No one cares about the low-level employees. Everyone is only interested in their own hikes and bonuses.
- Continuous nagging on the work assigned towards completion.
- Overloaded work with no work-life balance.

Title: Only join if you have money already
Pro: Good training, young people with high energy
Con: Only join if you already have money. You are expected to pay for your own papers that can amount to up to $1,000 or more, and they will only reimburse you if you pass, and even that would be after many months. Additionally, Human Resources are very vague, and will fire you even if you are trying to clarify issues that they did not ask in the first place under the guise of withholding of information. Only join if you are prepared to leave with a bad offboarding letter.

If you belong to the minority race. Be prepared to face casual racism on a daily basis - I.e. colleagues speaking in mandarin directly trash talking about you. Diversity and inclusion? Absolutely rubbish.

Title: Don't ruin your life
Pro: No pros at all, things only look good here from far away, you'll notice reality is different once you join
Con:
1. I have been working at DBS for the past couple of years, I have nothing but regrets as I was abused both physically and mentally by manager.
2. I got treated like a slave rather than an employee, I feel so helpless in these tough covid times where switching jobs is difficult.
3. My manager scolded me in front of everyone for one hour and humiliated me for something that wasn't even my fault, how am I supposed to deliver when the business analyst has no idea about requirements themselves? This used to happen before work from home as well, my manager grabbed my collar and pushed me while scolding me
4. Please don't join this company, I have no other reason to write this review than to create awareness, don't be fooled by the salary they offer, are you willing to sacrifice your reputation and respect? Are you willing to become a slave you gets abused every two weeks?

Thin twice before you join, I would recommend to join a lesser paying job with good work life balance and where employees are not treated like slaves.

I sacrificed my honor and respect for money, don't follow what I did, even if one person benefits from my warning, I will consider it worth my effort

Title: Mistake one would never want to do
Pro:
- DBS offers a high package for attracting people initially
- Good market value in the market but no hikes for the employee.
- I am happy to be working under a green field project where I got to learn otherwise it's mostly maintenance of the system.
Con:
People start to leave DBS within the year after they join. Company fails to retain them.
Many reasons for doing so:
- No future planning and goals for the work carried on.
- No sufficient hikes and bonuses
- Non-stop working and continuous pressure from heads
- Managers are inefficient and are self-obsessed
- No one cares about the low-level employees. Everyone is only interested in their own hikes and bonuses.
- Continuous nagging on the work assigned towards completion.
- Overloaded work with no work-life balance.

Title: Toxic place.. Zero work life balance
Pro: Benefits.. but they are shadowed by cons.
Con:
1.There is no planning for anything.. neither projects nor people’s career.
2.Requirements are not clear to product managers even till it’s ready for prod deployment.. I have experienced a project release which got reverted on user testing day in prod.
3. Most laughable thing : Mangers think and say that agile means we will it have requirements on day 1 , we need to ask questions, document the info. 
So, When should basic requirement analysis be done? After pushing developers to start Dev? Whose responsibility is this? Well in most of DBS Ibgt teams it’s developer’s responsibility to get requirements etc etc.
4. People’s career is joke to them, it goes like there is a requirement and oh here is a person who looks free just give it to him. Does it match his career goals ? Does he have knowledge on it? Does he need to learn and deliver? Nothing is thought of and deadlines are set without considering anything just a random date when user needs.. that’s it.
5. Employees are expected to work any number of hours and even after that they are not given enough support when needed. Thankless culture,
6. No pay balance at all .
7. Just a brain draining and stupid place to work at.
8. To top it all, HR ppl are of no use than sending out mails about policy changes .. this benefit that benefit.. wellness etc etc and in real nothing changes.

Title: Only join if you have money already
Pro: Good training, young people with high energy
Con: Only join if you already have money. You are expected to pay for your own papers that can amount to up to $1,000 or more, and they will only reimburse you if you pass, and even that would be after many months. Additionally, Human Resources are very vague, and will fire you even if you are trying to clarify issues that they did not ask in the first place under the guise of withholding of information. Only join if you are prepared to leave with a bad offboarding letter.

Title: Politics, lies and ridiculous expectations
Pro:
Pros

- Good Development team
- Relatively good extra benefits
Con:
1. Poor upper management planning when it comes to tech projects. Basically, whatever they want, they just open their mouth and expect you to finish it with a random deadline based on how they feel.
- They will over-commit to a deadline without listening to the development team's advice and without any consideration of the current workload and manpower available for the task.

- Goals, product features, and objectives shifts. Eg. in sprint 1, the goal was to get Model A working. But at the end of sprint 1, Management suddenly expects Model A, B, and C to work.
- Upper management expects developers to make up for their poor planning and management skills in the form of working on Sundays and Saturdays till 2 am.

Result: Engineers are overworked, underappreciated and management only provides lip service with no compensation. (And yes, we have worked Sat and Sundays for 3 weeks in a row).


2. Poor pay, Politics, and lies. Pay is not adjusted to the market rate. Despite getting external concrete offers, management lied about trying to increase the pay rate to match. Management only provides lip service without even actually speaking with HR etc. They provide excuses like not having enough budget, then immediately hire 2 -3 more junior engineers whom I have to train and are less qualified but with a better salaray?!
Upper management only rewards those who talk and demand a lot, not those who actually do the work.

Results: creates a lot of distrust between employees and management. Causes a lot of fiction and distrust between colleagues as everyone is fighting to be heard. Also encourages solo work to be done than collaborative work.

3. Upper management hires managers that are unskilled in terms of soft skills and hard skills. This causes a lot of issues between upper management, middle management, and developers.

- Middle management would present things and deadlines to upper management with no regard for developers. Everyone is just focused on what they want.

Title: 'Horribly' Overwork Employee
Pro: #NAME?
Con:
1. Assign heavy workload and expect things to be delivered within a short of time. Not because you have problem with time management, it is mainly because of understaff, meeting schedule too packed, more work piling up everyday, and work delay due to data source issues.
2. Long working hour because of workload too much and need to spend extra hours to do all the unnecessary trouble shooting thanks to the poor data migration process.
3. No work life balance. Not only you, your boss and your colleagues are all insanely hardworking. It's normal to work until 3-4am during Weekday. You thought you can take a break during Weekends, Annual Leave and Sick Leave? No way! You are entitled with 24days annual leave, but believe me, you will never use it for leisure purposes.
4. Nobody will care about your mental health and physical health. All they care is 'donation' and support 'volunteering' work outside of the company. So that branding can be promoted. 
5. High expectation from management and bosses, your works will never be appreciated.
6. Employee Turn-Over Rate is increasing. More and more people are leaving the company, at least 2-3 people you know will be leaving every month.
7. Meeting cultures are bad and some meetings are useless. You will spend one whole day to attend meeting, because most of the meetings last for at least 1hour,and some meetings are only 10% relevant to you or for your update/knowledge sharing only.
8. No time to do all those free courses, no time to do team bonding, no time to do small talk with your colleagues.
9. Bad planning and a lot of old problems need to clear. Some items have been pending for years or months, but nobody do it until you take the ownership.
10. People are not very helpful because they are too busy with their own work and clearing backlog. When you need help, the only way is to ping the person multiple times or escalate through emails cc his/her boss.

Title: Like an apple, shiny on the outside, rotten in its core
Pro:
This depends on your luck. If you are reporting to a good boss/department, perhaps you may enjoy what you do.
If you are a top performer (depends if your boss and others acknowledge this and likes you), compensation is competitive.
Once again, depending on your boss, work hours may be flexible as long as you get your job done.
Con:
You will find more free riders in DBS than most companies out there. A lot of people are hired to blow hot air and do nothing else. Yet they are the ones being promoted quickly and compensated. Don’t try to look for team spirit, everybody is just trying to one up each other.
Again it depends on your luck, but good luck finding a paradise in DBS. Of course if you are one of the hot air blowers above, then life is peachy and you can be prepared to retire here comfortably.

Title: DAH2 is a great organization to start career with
Pro:
Pay is better than most companies.
Manager and upper management supported immensely when I was going through personal issues (loss of loved ones in family).
Good WFH options during the pandemic, as I am able to do 100% of my work from home, never had to go to office since the last one year.
Excellent increment, company rewards loyal employees.
Work load mostly manageable.
Some use cases are very fun to work in analytics.
Good hackathon and data focus, and frequent contests with rewards.
Free transport and coffee if you come to office, reimbursable internet bills if you are working from home.
Good coding culture. Some colleagues are brilliant in coding, you can learn a lot from them.
Insurance policy is great, got cashless claim on a surgery and it covered everything except a few antibiotics.
Separate flexible benefits that can be used for dental, gym membership, etc. Was able to get WFH office setup via the extra amount provided for pandemic related expenditure.
CTC documents are very transparent, no misleading options to inflate CTC.
Good gifts given by the company to employees.
Good training and focus on learning and development.
Mandatory block leave for all employees, very useful to relax.
Con:
It is a bank, so there are some restrictions on the work laptop and VPN, so you don't have a lot of freedom there.
Deployment and release process is a bit problematic but they are working on streamlining it, it's much better than it was last year.
Sometimes have to work late or on weekends. However, they are trying to reduce this and provide compensatory leave if you work on a holiday.

Title: Fusion between a traditional bank and a tech company
Pro: I like the culture in DBS that encourages me to do my job with integrity and give honest feedback without the worry of repercussion. DBS also cares about its employees and are taking actions to improve employee life.
Con: DBS is a big and complex organisation. Sometimes you need to clear lots of stakeholders to get things done.

Title: Nil

Title: 'Horribly' Overwork Employee
Pro: #NAME?
Con:
1. Assign heavy workload and expect things to be delivered within a short of time. Not because you have problem with time management, it is mainly because of understaff, meeting schedule too packed, more work piling up everyday, and work delay due to data source issues.
2. Long working hour because of workload too much and need to spend extra hours to do all the unnecessary trouble shooting thanks to the poor data migration process.
3. No work life balance. Not only you, your boss and your colleagues are all insanely hardworking. It's normal to work until 3-4am during Weekday. You thought you can take a break during Weekends, Annual Leave and Sick Leave? No way! You are entitled with 24days annual leave, but believe me, you will never use it for leisure purposes.
4. Nobody will care about your mental health and physical health. All they care is 'donation' and support 'volunteering' work outside of the company. So that branding can be promoted. 
5. High expectation from management and bosses, your works will never be appreciated.
6. Employee Turn-Over Rate is increasing. More and more people are leaving the company, at least 2-3 people you know will be leaving every month.
7. Meeting cultures are bad and some meetings are useless. You will spend one whole day to attend meeting, because most of the meetings last for at least 1hour,and some meetings are only 10% relevant to you or for your update/knowledge sharing only.
8. No time to do all those free courses, no time to do team bonding, no time to do small talk with your colleagues.
9. Bad planning and a lot of old problems need to clear. Some items have been pending for years or months, but nobody do it until you take the ownership.
10. People are not very helpful because they are too busy with their own work and clearing backlog. When you need help, the only way is to ping the person multiple times or escalate through emails cc his/her boss.

Title: Like an apple, shiny on the outside, rotten in its core
Pro:
This depends on your luck. If you are reporting to a good boss/department, perhaps you may enjoy what you do.
If you are a top performer (depends if your boss and others acknowledge this and likes you), compensation is competitive.
Once again, depending on your boss, work hours may be flexible as long as you get your job done.
Con:
You will find more free riders in DBS than most companies out there. A lot of people are hired to blow hot air and do nothing else. Yet they are the ones being promoted quickly and compensated. Don’t try to look for team spirit, everybody is just trying to one up each other.
Again it depends on your luck, but good luck finding a paradise in DBS. Of course if you are one of the hot air blowers above, then life is peachy and you can be prepared to retire here comfortably.

Title: Good Bank but Dont join CORPORATE SALARY ACCOUNT SEGMENT
Pro:
1.Company is good but SALARY ACCOUNT segment sucks Dont join if you want to save carrier
2.Good culture in other departments accept salary account senior managers behave like goons.

Con:
1.Salary account segment have very bad culture because of senior management
2.Do not join as CPE its a contract based job and they will never renew your contract after 1 year and will give you false promises that they will make you permanent. Trust me it will not happen its a gimmick to hire you.
3.They can change your role anytime once you are hired and start giving you unreasonable targets to achieve and give you so much pressure that you need to quit the job.
4.I have worked in DBS and more then 80 employees quit from last 2 years because of so much of pressure. They wont fire you they will give you so much of pressure or will put you in PIP that you need to quit.

Title: Join Here If You Wanna Ruin Your Life!
Pro:
Technology stack
Learning opportunities
Office infrastructure
Transport facility
Con:
Horrible work pressure

Work life balance is a joke here

Not paid proportionately, freshers (not IIT / NIT / IIM grads) might earn higher than a 6 years experienced, so negotiate higher initially. Due to high basic, tax deductions are very high, thanks to our Govt. as well

Notice period and buyout option are probably the worst

'C2E' LOB is probably the worst

Good technology stack but you might get a chance to watch those from distance only and work in normal business logic development with vanilla coding

Singapore management team is not employee focused

Always tend to get a workload of 5 people get done by 2 people only, that also reduce to 1 if possible

Work from home was usually possible always but management never encouraged or allowed any, just due to covid they were forced to allow it, that too late while others already started. WFH is not a boon but curse here, your 9hrs of office duration gets easily stretched to 12 - 13 hrs usually.

Title: Amazing People with string ethics

Title: DAH2 is a great organization to start career with
Pro:
Pay is better than most companies.
Manager and upper management supported immensely when I was going through personal issues (loss of loved ones in family).
Good WFH options during the pandemic, as I am able to do 100% of my work from home, never had to go to office since the last one year.
Excellent increment, company rewards loyal employees.
Work load mostly manageable.
Some use cases are very fun to work in analytics.
Good hackathon and data focus, and frequent contests with rewards.
Free transport and coffee if you come to office, reimbursable internet bills if you are working from home.
Good coding culture. Some colleagues are brilliant in coding, you can learn a lot from them.
Insurance policy is great, got cashless claim on a surgery and it covered everything except a few antibiotics.
Separate flexible benefits that can be used for dental, gym membership, etc. Was able to get WFH office setup via the extra amount provided for pandemic related expenditure.
CTC documents are very transparent, no misleading options to inflate CTC.
Good gifts given by the company to employees.
Good training and focus on learning and development.
Mandatory block leave for all employees, very useful to relax.
Con:
It is a bank, so there are some restrictions on the work laptop and VPN, so you don't have a lot of freedom there.
Deployment and release process is a bit problematic but they are working on streamlining it, it's much better than it was last year.
Sometimes have to work late or on weekends. However, they are trying to reduce this and provide compensatory leave if you work on a holiday.

Title: Fusion between a traditional bank and a tech company
Pro: I like the culture in DBS that encourages me to do my job with integrity and give honest feedback without the worry of repercussion. DBS also cares about its employees and are taking actions to improve employee life.
Con: DBS is a big and complex organisation. Sometimes you need to clear lots of stakeholders to get things done.

Title: Fantastic perks, lots of resources, very hierarchical.
Pro:
Employee benefits is unparalleled. It's an extremely fun and volatile place to work at as everyone is young and hungry to prove themselves. There are a lot of awards and recognitions to achieve and if you work hard, and if you do, you will get compensated handsomely.

If you navigate your way smartly, you will find huge growth on the personal and professional level.
Con:
- There's a lot of bootlicking up the ladder.
- Word spreads like wildfire within the distribution
- As with anywhere else, there is politicking.
- Do you have a hobby? A favourite pastime? Be prepared to reminisce about it a lot because it's going to

Title: Disappointingly incompetent management
Pro: Reasonable benefits. Reasonable remuneration. Despite what 99% of employees believe, you will neither be challenged nor working long hours.
Con:
Technology management long past their best-buy dates. Technically incompetent with a micromanagement focus. Staff are encouraged to follow and add to ever growing processes, many of which have no place in modern IT. 

Senior leadership often have no external experience, are hired from recommendation or come from areas like building management. Others run roughshod, shouting and raging. 

HR have introduced appalling training programmes and negatively impact hiring by averaging salaries to commodity roles. 

Finance have never updated a policy and their processes remain like a bank from the 1980s. 

Despite excellent senior management, DBS will never excel. 

The company should appeal to the mediocre and individuals who are happy with being average.

Title: MY VOICE (annual survey) IS NOT ANONYMOUS
Pro: Good pay and benefits but other that nothing else
Con:
DAH2 management and HR stresses a lot about my voice and ask you to submit honest feedback so that they can use that to improve, but in actuality your managers threaten you to provide good ratings to them. If anyone provides a negative feedback, they find out who that person is and take it on themselves to ruin their careers. My manager explicitly called out my name in a meeting and openly showed my feedback to my team members.
They can narrow down such feedback by slicing and dicing etc and use it to target individuals giving poor scores.
Then they waited for the year end review process to halt my progress and gave me bad ratings, without any proper communication, reasons and threaten to put me in performance improvement when i tried to be reasonable.
Never had such atrocious experience in my 10 plus years of experience
HR doesn’t seem to have much power either

Title: Very low salary - No hikes / Bonus
Pro:
Pros are some cheap employee benefits like Cab and Gym memberships.
But many cons not to join DBS Asia hub 2
Con:
1. Within the organisation hikes are very low and this time around they have decided to not give bonus also which is highly demotivating for all employees.
2. Amount of work which employees do is not being considered at all, not many willing to join seeing low salary
3. Worst company with project handlings as most of the project starts and after some time goes into dustbin.
4. One of the illogical and worst company pay policy. Just for example: if given a promotion,hike is not mandatory. 
5. Ratings and review system is totally confusing as it's based very little on performance
6. I can guarantee for sure that senior managements are worst here as people leave organisation like anything but they do not care.
7. Too much work pressure to handle from business side - Singapore but it's not being considered to recognise
ONLY Suggestion: Do not join DBS Asia Hub2 and waste your career time, this can be worst experience of your life

Title: Too many clients + workload and not enough employees
Pro:
Staff preferential loan interest rate
Helpful colleagues despite the workload
Con:
The customer base is too large and there are not enough staff support across all departments, be it IT, compliance, front office and credit. For example, the credit department has to support all 3 segments of Treasures, TPC and Private Banking (that is a LARGE number of clients), and that team has less than 15 people.

The compliance department is seriously understaffed too, with many of them working till late at night. I'm pretty sure MAS Notice 626 states to allocate sufficient resources to monitoring/compliance functions based on the size of the bank, and I am not seeing that happening.

Various departments take forever to revert, not because they are incompetent; there is simply too much workload for everyone.

Title: Best and worst experience in T&O
Pro: Meet friendly and capable people - be they local or foreigners.
Con:
1. Long working hours and many are doing 2-3 people's job.
2. Stable systems are overlooked and deemed "simple " or "easy" while systems that have problems every week are praised and people supporting it promoted every year.
3. There are entire floors of foreigners. So much so that they started a satellite office overseas in 2016 but yet these floors still exist and continue to grow. Majority are doing jobs that locals can do. Many are hired through personal relationships and not by merit. 
4. HR is only interested at managing headcount and cost by evading the 17% (Employer CPF contribution) by hiring foreigners hidden in the many outsourcing companies they use.
5. Unqualified staff increase troubleshooting issues by days and even weeks. Senior staff can screw up simple cert installations, server hardening and configurations. The best part is these people still manage to get promoted and bring in even more unqualified people.

Title: Great co-workers but toxic managers
Pro: Great people and challenging environment. Great respect for the CEO and his vision who brought DBS to be the best bank in the world.
Con:
Depending in which organization you sit, you might encounter toxic behaviour from management. I'm specifically referring to the Digital Consumer Banking Technology, Big Data / AI group, which I'm part of.

Its leader drives the group like a dictator, often imposing questionable choices, micromanaging every piece of work and showing zero respect for people who put their time and effort in designing the best possible solutions. She will completely overturn decisions taken by her team, and when things do not go as planned (often because of decisions that she took) she will start blaming people publicly, yelling and screaming at everyone in meetings. People are so afraid of her and worried for their job that they do not have the courage to go against her anymore. This has created a toxic environment where everyone is encouraged to "suck up" to her and blame someone else when things do not go as planned. 

During the course of the years I have seen her hiring very strong individuals, throwing them in the "garbage" and forcing them to leave after few months or years just because they started disagreeing with her decisions. The unfortunate thing is that the bank keeps loosing smart people just because of her toxic behaviour and her total lack of respect for any human being.

Work recognition is solely at her discretion and only people who has learnt to "suck up" to her can progress in their career.

Title: Do not fall to money trap, think thrice before you accept offer, your life will become hell.
Pro: Nothing, yeah but lot of money they can give to trap you to suck your blood out.
Con:
Worked in DBS DAH2 more than 3 years, worst decision of my life to join DBS.
If you want to give away your peace of life go for DBS, reasons given below.

1. Managers are treated like god, no respect for other employees,you will be treated like a slave.
2. No escalation matrix.
3. Hire and Fire policy.
4. HR`s are very arrogant and behave like Gandhi`s ---key if you raise any concern.
5. If you do any escalation top to bottom whole management will work against you.
6. How much good work you do dont matter all depends on Managers liking or disliking.
7. Managers hire their relatives and grow them and frustrate and torture other with full support from HR and top mgmt.
8. Managers dont understand Agile and dont have management skilss, will never allow you to grow.
9. Hike and Bonus will be distributed to loved onces like toffee`s, skills or performance does not matter.
10. Every one dance like a puppet infront of Singapore folks.
11.So if you want to losse your peace of mind, your family happiness and ready to dance on the tune created by a brainless manager and his Singapore counterparts, go for DBS.

Title: Great co-workers but toxic managers
Pro: Great people and challenging environment. Great respect for the CEO and his vision who brought DBS to be the best bank in the world.
Con:
Depending in which organization you sit, you might encounter toxic behaviour from management. I'm specifically referring to the Digital Consumer Banking Technology, Big Data / AI group, which I'm part of.

Its leader drives the group like a dictator, often imposing questionable choices, micromanaging every piece of work and showing zero respect for people who put their time and effort in designing the best possible solutions. She will completely overturn decisions taken by her team, and when things do not go as planned (often because of decisions that she took) she will start blaming people publicly, yelling and screaming at everyone in meetings. People are so afraid of her and worried for their job that they do not have the courage to go against her anymore. This has created a toxic environment where everyone is encouraged to "suck up" to her and blame someone else when things do not go as planned. 

During the course of the years I have seen her hiring very strong individuals, throwing them in the "garbage" and forcing them to leave after few months or years just because they started disagreeing with her decisions. The unfortunate thing is that the bank keeps loosing smart people just because of her toxic behaviour and her total lack of respect for any human being.

Work recognition is solely at her discretion and only people who has learnt to "suck up" to her can progress in their career.

Title: Working in DBS Bank

DBS onboarding procedure will make you sense more relaxed. 
Working culture in DBS is one the utmost and when comes to the technology you will be with the current market standards.
Leaders or the management of DBS are quite easily accessible and are more approachable enough to share anything.
Appreciation and the reviews in DBS will make you more encouraging.
Facilities in DBS like transport, pantry areas and work spaces are extraordinary.
Con: Only work in Office, no work from home.

Con: Nothing glaring at the moment

Title: Top down approach, good for retirement
Pro:
Safe job, good for retirement if you’re looking to stay. Fixed progression and not much worry of how you’ll promote till you reach middle management. Being in the corporate segment, promotion is easier than the consumer segment. 

People are generally nice, politics happens but if you put departments aside, general attitude is that everyone is just there as a job, not to cut each other’s throats. 

DBS definitely does have some structure and processes in place being a large Corp, but has some ways to go to improve staff mindset to grow out of a domestic company culture.
Con:
Upper Management in SME segment are top down, not responsive to feedback, treats the company like an SME. A lot of things are done specifically for PR purposes, instead of long term vision of what is good for the customer and company. 

Recent years have seen multiple reorgs of the IBG34 segment. 

The working style from the top of segment is non strategic and instant gratifying. Without C suite expectation of digitalization and that being put in the score card, some things would not have happened. Multiple projects were undertaken instead of focusing on 2-3 key pillars to tackle and undertake.  

Instead of pouring dollars everywhere like over an ice cream sundae, instead think of how to create the most effective means of focusing the dollars for major effect. An example would be to improve internal platforms and adopt external tools like most digital banks.

Title: Top down approach, good for retirement
Pro:
Safe job, good for retirement if you’re looking to stay. Fixed progression and not much worry of how you’ll promote till you reach middle management. Being in the corporate segment, promotion is easier than the consumer segment. 

People are generally nice, politics happens but if you put departments aside, general attitude is that everyone is just there as a job, not to cut each other’s throats. 

DBS definitely does have some structure and processes in place being a large Corp, but has some ways to go to improve staff mindset to grow out of a domestic company culture.
Con:
Upper Management in SME segment are top down, not responsive to feedback, treats the company like an SME. A lot of things are done specifically for PR purposes, instead of long term vision of what is good for the customer and company. 

Recent years have seen multiple reorgs of the IBG34 segment. 

The working style from the top of segment is non strategic and instant gratifying. Without C suite expectation of digitalization and that being put in the score card, some things would not have happened. Multiple projects were undertaken instead of focusing on 2-3 key pillars to tackle and undertake.  

Instead of pouring dollars everywhere like over an ice cream sundae, instead think of how to create the most effective means of focusing the dollars for major effect. An example would be to improve internal platforms and adopt external tools like most digital banks.

HR is no use. I think HR needs to take  training first then organize training for us. They are doing only one thing - flattering the senior leader so that they can get promoted ( which hapens always) this company doesnt derseve good people.

when few people speak up against the wrong things, they get thrown out. I know such people who are suffering. Mr Mohit Kapoor who was good and modest is also leaving and now we will have more control from SG and these random C2E leaders who have no values or humbleness at all.

Title: Customer Service at 2 different depts
Pro:
Depends on which dept you work with. Great boss at IBG, worst Boss at contact centre. Extreme differences. 
Tons of perks
Supportive and understanding boss at IBG who care about you and your family.
Con:
Contact centre -  management has no empathy especially when you took leave for urgent family matter. They will stressed you by calling you Everyday to ask when you are coming back to work. Need to ballot for popular days to take leave eg cny, Christmas. 
There has a special HR for contact centre only who will only side the management. 
Thankfully I managed to transfer to IBG which is more human. The work life significant changed Fr hell to heaven.

Title: Private Bank ARM overworked
Pro: The ARM in DBSPB does everything for the RM and ICs, so you literally get insight into every single function from account opening and KYC to investment portfolio construction, order taking, dealing and tracking, credit approval, credit monitoring and review, everything you can think of and cannot think of. And there's also retail banking stuff (credit cards, cash withdrawal, CNY new notes omg)
Con: On the flip side, you literally get paid half of the foreign banks for triple the amount of work load... and if you don't get a good boss, then good luck because the RM will always always always push the responsibilities and blame to the ARM.

- All the data you need are in the system but you need to access them one by one and interpret them manually just t

Title: Think before you join.. Money is not everything..
Pro:
- Good infrastructure and facility.
- Transport facility.
- More cash in hand.

Positives for some people.
- If you are good in marketing yourself(means you really dont do anything but know how to show that you doing great) then this is the place for
Con:
- No proper framework to assess the individual during appraisal. People rate you based on their perception. No objectivity in rating people. 
- The leadership and HR blindly believe the marketing people only(people who don't really work but do show off).

Title: Slow paced and delusional
Pro:
Such a slow pace of work that you can balance other commitments.
No one ever gets fired, no matter how useless.
Singapore exposure
Great office at Nariman point- the view is outstanding from the higher floors and the seating is agile (not fixed)
Con:
A lot of the HR policies are just on paper- they sell them to you when you are joining. Example: Flexi-time and Work from home. In reality the managers rarely approve any of these. HR is a huge team which is largely incompetent- not sure which gutter they hire them from. None of the HR working at DBS would be employable elsewhere.
The India managing committee is a mixed bag. The heads of the business functions are jokers, some of the support function like finance and legal are fine- but marketing and HR are really sub-standard.
Singapore interferes (and often creates a mess) in India functioning. 
Too many tedious, unnecessary processes which slow down everything

Title: The Best Yet to Be
Pro: A very diverse regional workforce, probably most diverse among some of the big local companies; very strong leadership and momentum to drive shareholder values; great transformation efforts; many employees journey efforts; great talent within the organisation; growth momentum.
Con:
There are still some legacy mentality,  process, thinking and even people politics which are hindering the pace of change and speed to react to the market changes. 
Middle management is inconsistent and some staff are not as driven (or could be complacent).

Title: DAH 2 should be your worst case option to join.
Pro: I didn't see it has any additional or unique benefits than  any other product based company.
Con:
No work Life balance. 
Too much micro management.
Not flexible in the matter of timings.
No work from home.
You better ignore joining here even though you get the best package because if you join, soon you'll realize what biggest mistake you made.. :). 
Not suitable especially for the married folks.
You will definitely feel that you got stuck because for your experience DAH 2 hr knows that opportunities will be less outside . That's why they prefer to recruit more experienced folks , generally 7+yrs.
Luckily I have realized early and moved out and there is no single day at DAH 2 where I went to office with a whole hearted smile.
Follow fail-fast principle to quit from here or else you will stuck forever. 
This is from my personal experience, if you still want to feel how it will be in DAH 2... It's up to you... :). Good luck from your well wisher.. :)

Title: Don't join at all
Pro: Fancy Infra, free bus, free tea coffee
Con:
Uncountable, 

Initially HR will treat you as son/ daughter in law later they treat you like waste, Don't expect any help or support, you are your own . 
The moment you put down your paper you are just like traitor for them, they start treating you like enemy. 

Work culture, after few months they start realising you as you are just a slave for them, you worth nothing ,do as they say, long story short you start realizing yourself as a slave and that's truth. Below manager every one is feeling same. 

Manager is your master do as they say else be ready for consequences. This is open and well known fact and policy there. You are not supposed to stand for your self. You are expected to work 24x7 not only expected you have to work that much time, irrespective you have any emergency or personal problem, it doesn't matter. 
Manager can call you and ask you to come down at office even if you are I  hospital, he simply says you can go hospital later or what you are doing there , doctor is the one who does.

Title: Singaporean bank culture. External image is changing, but still decades away from foreign banks in culture/capability.
Pro: Pay seems to be at market. Lots of resources compared to other banks (in terms of headcount per team vs foreign banks). Strong retail bank and technology is improving. Stable job security. Relevancy as a corporate bank in Singapore. Transaction banking capability is improving fast. Leadership in transaction banking moving in the right direction.
Con: Still has a strong Singaporean culture compared to foreign banks. Learning and development from seniors is lacking. Banking knowledge development is lacking, ie. Not developing the skillset for future roles. Middle management VP to MD level likes to keep status quo. Deals not as exciting as foreign banks, and very short term thinking. Leaders do not have the varied experiences of working for other organisations (DBS whole career). Hours unusually long (face time). Lots of disgruntled employees.

Title: Great life experience. A stepping stone to be in tbe customer service /banking industry.
Pro: The best reasons are colleagues that care to lend a helping hand when newbies does not know how to go about a new transaction. That. Just that.
Con: Too many to mention. No work life balance at all. Some of the seniors are too rigid to their old-lifestyle that they never give the newbies a chance to speak up on new innovations. And,  having no work life balance makes the body system breakdown. You can't afford to take MC at all. MC is not an entitlement here.

Title: Feedback
Pro:
Nice infrastructure if you work as a direct employee.
They are evolving with new Technologies.
Con:
Poor Project Management in development. They say agile but they don't exactly follow agile. 
Difficult understanding what people from Singapore say during requirement gathering.
No respect if you work as a vendor. 
No work life balance. Production Support job is very stressful. They say on call and do not pay if there isn't a production Incident which means that you have to be at home waiting for SMS alert. There is no shift planning in some teams and you will be called anytime by DBS Leads.
No work from home option because of regulatory reasons but India is not Singapore where you get MRT anytime. No Google access in ODCs which means you won't be able to read Technical Stuff sometimes if you want to.

Title: Good staff benefits but poor work-life balance
Pro:
- Decent compensation: above average in terms of starting salary for fresh university graduates 
- Good staff benefits: 24 days of annual leave + 2 days of family leave (effectively it's annual leave that you can't carry forward)
Con:
- Poor work life balance: frequent OT. Almost impossible to complete one's work without doing OT on a regular basis. In fact, OT is like a "default" activity.
- Management is overly ambitious, introducing more changes and taking on more projects than the

Title: Horrible company. Does not value top talent pool.
Pro: Nothing to talk about. Absolutely disappointing.
Con:
Elitist mindset - Management Associates / Graduate Executives get all the perks and benefits, even though many of them don't make the cut. Consistent top performers (without career acceleration tracks) are constantly undermined and underpaid even though they may be much better than the MAs/GEs.

MAs / GEs can be paid as much as an AVP with the bank for 17 years. Even escalation to management and raising concerns to Human Resources on such glaring inequality results in a token few hundred dollars pay adjustment.

Not asking the bank to pay everyone equally, but to at least ensure competitive pay for TOP performers. However this seems to be too much for them as they value their MAs/GEs like precious gold.

After working in this bank for a number of years, my pay has stagnated even though I am consistently recognised as my department's top performer. Record profits, but no record increments or bonuses. I am now leaving for greener pastures with a taste of disgust in my mouth.

Title: Excellent work place
Pro:
1. Good Working environment.
2. Good Infra
3. Flat organisational structure which makes it easier to interact with your colleagues and bosses (i.e No cubicle system)
4. Best HR policies ( Believe me best means literally )
Con:
1.  The structure is based in such a way that for critical decisions also it has to go through Singapore office, which mostly becomes a huge hindrance at work as all the work in pipeline get jammed.
2. DBS Mumbai specifically needs deployment of innovation center as the churn rate amongst fresh graduates is high, reason being the liberty to improvise on existing processes is not there yet.

Title: Client Facing Role (non-sales)
Pro: Work-life balance, optional family medical benefits, annual leave 24 days and with additional childcare leave. Flexi-cash benefit for lifestyle/dental/insurance. IT technology are improvised and up-to-date. Many systems are available to use at work which are very good compared to some banks which don't pull in resource to upgrade systems, intranet information are well-equipped. Other department staff are generally helpful. Can find a handful of colleagues working in the bank for many years. Bonus is better than EU banks and competitive with local banks.
Con: Too many Management hierarchies, management politics, too many systems sometimes to find what you want. Each team/business unit have their own work-culture. Really dependable on your direct supervisor and management to make it a joyful working environment.

Title: Work life balance
Pro:
Singaporean bank - many singaporeans around. Pro-Asian
Work life balance present at times.
Con:
Use of singlish/Hokkien/cantonese/chinese is common here. Feels unprofessional at times. Joined straight after graduation, and to hear colleagues (staff who have been with the bank for 15 years and more) speak languages other than english feels  unprofessional.

In addition, graduates from local uni not as competitively paid than if they were to work in foreign bank. DBS is losing graduates/talent from local U fast, after 2-3 years. Many peers have left, from across bank wide.

Title: Think before you join.. Money is not everything..
Pro:
- Good infrastructure and facility.
- Transport facility.
- More cash in hand.

Positives for some people.
- If you are good in marketing yourself(means you really dont do anything but know how to show that you doing great) then this is the place for
Con:
- No proper framework to assess the individual during appraisal. People rate you based on their perception. No objectivity in rating people. 
- The leadership and HR blindly believe the marketing people only(people who don't really work but do show off).

Title: Growing Bank
Pro: DBSI is a growing company where I can expand my knowledge specially in Digital Product. In addition, since the integration with ANZ, we experienced many challenges in our daily activities. As a result, we need to think creatively and effectively to overcome those challenges.
Con: In my opinion, with the growing company and technology, DBSI should have a strong and robust standard in order to balance between customer experinece and security.

Title: Great place to learn and progress
Pro: Provides good training class for new employees. Although the learning curve is steep, senior colleagues are all very friendly and willing to teach and guide you along the way. Pay is very attractive compare to other local banks in Singapore. Work culture tend to vary from different branch manager or service manager, but overall they managers try to avoid work politics and lay a healthy work environment. Continuous learning opportunity!
Con: Long working hours. People with difficulty managing time or come out with a suitable daily routine would find themselves wearing out very quickly. Work with an end goal in mind!

Title: ITT SG Leadership condones DAH2 senior leadership behaviour
Pro: DBS is more than family to long timers. No one person can be made accountable for worsening the culture of ITT at DAH2. In the interest of well being of people, it is urged that people use 360 degree feedback, pigeon hole and my voice comments to get issues addressed. It is not sensible to malign reputation of DBS on glassdoor. If you think you are being unheard by HRBP and various forums, reach out to CEO for inputs and help.
Con: None that I have witnessed in last decade.

Title: Great Company
Pro:
1. Bank believes strongly in talent rotation. Priority is given to internal staff to apply for transfer.
2. Good leaders and top management who are capable of steering the company to greater heights.
Con:
1. Poor work life balance and long working hours.
2. Does not pay as well compared to other banks.
3. People in top positions are usually foreign talent. Hires a lot of foreigners compared to Singapore Citizens.

Title: DAH 2 should be your worst case option to join.
Pro: I didn't see it has any additional or unique benefits than  any other product based company.
Con:
No work Life balance. 
Too much micro management.
Not flexible in the matter of timings.
No work from home.
You better ignore joining here even though you get the best package because if you join, soon you'll realize what biggest mistake you made.. :). 
Not suitable especially for the married folks.
You will definitely feel that you got stuck because for your experience DAH 2 hr knows that opportunities will be less outside . That's why they prefer to recruit more experienced folks , generally 7+yrs.
Luckily I have realized early and moved out and there is no single day at DAH 2 where I went to office with a whole hearted smile.
Follow fail-fast principle to quit from here or else you will stuck forever. 
This is from my personal experience, if you still want to feel how it will be in DAH 2... It's up to you... :). Good luck from your well wisher.. :)

Title: A place for those who like to make a difference!
Pro: The bank is changing for the better, new breakthrough, more creative ways to perform work, suitable for those who wanted to contribute and make a difference, The bank is growing, there is a lot of opportunity and many new job created.  CEO and his one down are committed to practice what they preach. Great place to work for woman and working mother.
Con: Since the bank changing quite rapidly, with more diversity, understanding the way people working and their culture is crucial for survival tips in this company.

Title: Decent but certainly could improve.
Pro: Decent pay, cab facility, understanding teammates, decent stack, active upper management & active HR teams.
Con:
The company is in a middle of a transition from it's core old banking firm to a more technical mindset firm. This transition isn't uniform, some departments are way ahead in the migration than few others.  

In respect to my department: 

1. Lack of challenging CS problems. 
2. Drastic code/scope changes will require Singapore management involvement which stops you as an engineer from truly making a great product.  
3. Sometimes monotonous work.
4. Poor timings & No work from home. 

DBS will slowly but surely transition into a proper tech company however most employees rightly so, wouldn't want to wait that long.

Title: Good culture, mediocre benefits
Pro: #NAME?
Con: #NAME?

Title: Organisation is good place for growth
Pro: Hardwork pays off in DBS with extremely good promotion and recognition with top management including interviews with the ceo and team bonding exercises with leadership. Right place to be if you want due recognition and opportunity for fast track growth.
Con: Fairly new in the wealth management market. DBS Bank Strategy is a bit confusing for general customer who may be looking for an all solutions provider or complete banking package. DBs needs to refocus on its core competencies to outline and postion itself on a significant market share.

Title: No. of days leave is the most attractive
Pro: 24- that's quite a high number of days of leave you're entitled to. Awesome, but many don't get to clear the leave cus there's always so much work, and so many freeloaders in the team.
Con: Bosses like to hire "the best" talents - either people who have obviously oversold their credentials, or people who're really good in what they do but aren't utilised well.

Title: Good future for the bank on the outside but internal problems
Pro: Employment benefits. Enthusiastic culture about things they are trying to drive. Effort to open communication channels with staff straight to top management.
Con: People - many seniors have the dated mindset. Enforcing hierarchy in management style. Difficult to bring change. Split locations make travelling tedious. Normal working hours are beyond normal if you are a responsible employee who won't just drop your work when the minimum knockoff time is reached if work is not complete.

Title: BAD!!!!
Pro:
benefits are ok.. 24 days of annual leave, etc... but if you are sales staff, and if your sale is bad, you will not dare to take leave. 

A good platform to jump ship...
Con:
Depend on the branch manager you work with. Mine experience is horrifying.... Ex-boss keep screaming and shouting over some tiny matters... And super Micro-manage.... Compension is bad... 

And keep pressing sales staff to "sell" certain funds or new launched  products, though the top mangament would say "need -based selling"....

Title: Awesome employees but worst managers in HYD
Pro:
-Scope to learn new technologies
-You can learn to work in hectic environment
-Good competitions for ideas and innovation with good prizes
-There are some good initiatives by EDs
-Good working hours 8.30am to 5.30pm if your manager is good
Con:
-Some managers (VP, SVP) are saddist and they have very negative political mindset
-Hike is not as good as compared to market during annual performance cycles 
-Some managers don't have technical skills and they don't understand the system and expect to d

Title: Political Company
Pro: Infrastructure is good as it is new setup, learning and training are good, cab facility is provided.Online Learning sites are good
Con:
No recognition for people who really work instead awards are given to those who show off. Earlier Manager shows favourtism and does not anything technical
Managers at hyd cannot make any decisions and are dependent on singapore people. The hyd center is vendor to singapore. cost cutting has started as bonus are very less.Wasting money on infrastruture and unnecessary events.
Initial Pay was good when joined but no good hike.Makes  people move from one team to other team without considering their interest and acceptance

Title: Bank that is growing very rapidly and its growth speed brings on numerous new opportunities for the employees
Pro:
- Stable and overly competitive or political
- Improving HR benefits
- Co-workers are genuinely supportive and considerate
- Very rewarding if you have a supportive boss or if you are in the MAP
Con:
- limited overseas exposure or overseas posting
- no flexible work hours or arrangements (the culture is not deep set yet).
- can be political as many colleagues have been in DBS for more than 10 years
- Slow to react and difficult to implement new ide

Title: Good benefits but highly political organization
Pro: Good staff benefits and working environment. Work life balance.
Con: Highly political company. Top leadership is clear with their direction but their one or  two downs are reluctant to give direction and take accountability. Often, leaving working level in various department as boats heading to different directions.

Title: Why DBS
Pro: A bank with a very strong balance sheet and AA- credit rating. Provides good platform for employees to thrive and harness their potential as it works with a  start-up style culture despite of being a large bank. This is the largest bank in Singapore, so if you are seeking employment within Singapore, this is where one would want to be.
Con: The bank's core competence is Asia though it has international product offerings and has presence in international markets.

Title: Good to work
Pro:
- Safe local bank to work.
- good work life balance.
Con:
- compensation is not good compared to other MNCs.
- For new joiners its a struggle to learn as no documents are available or not shared by seniors.
- No training given to new joiners and is expected to learn everything themselves.
- Processes are not

Title: Great company to work with
Pro: They would react to the macro trend very quickly, taking the initiative to improve the corporate brand. They treated the staff nicely and offered a lot of training opportunities.
Con: The career prospect was good for some departments, but not all. And they seemed to prefer recruiting ready-to-work talents from outside rather than grooming home-made talents, which was frustrating. The lower rank people had little promotion and advancement opportunities. Worked overtime every single day - 8:30am to 8:30pm at least, but maybe it is the 'usual' working hours for banking industry.

Title: Asian Bank
Pro:
Great work-life balance. I always got off at 6pm sharp. 
Above avg compensation level. It used to be higher than other banks but after 2011 its expansion reduced and so does the salary.
Con: There are lots of office politics probably because it's an Asian bank. You have to guess what others think, especially what bosses are thinking about. You need to be careful of using words.

Title: Generous bank but management not yet there
Pro:
-Lots of benefits since it's a big company
-Lots of leaves
-Good medical benefits
-Nice Colleagues (Contact Centre Department to be specific)
Con:
-Understaffed
-A lot of KPI's that stresses employees
-A lot of changes employees have to keep up in a weekly/daily basis
-Some of the management don't know what they are doing, everything seems experimental
-Career progression is slow
-Lots of polit

Title: Good place to be in
Pro:
I have left the bank but will encourage people to join DBS should opportunity arises. 

People are generously nice there across business and support units. I happened to join the right team with good managers and supportive colleagues. While OT is expected in banking and especially in operation, my OT hours was acceptable (occasionally beyond 7pm).  

Overall benefits are good with the  most generous AL among the 3 local banks. 

Internal transfer are  widely advocated in the bank.
Con: I would have stayed on if there is better bonus and increment.

Title: Horrible experience, did absolutely NOTHING to my career growth
Pro:
- Decent wage
- Some hardworking, talented and genuinely good people.
Con:
- NO work-life balance, CRAZY workload.    
- Terrible/unprofessional leadership - its not what you know but WHO you know.  Dodges responsiblities but will not hesitate to take YOUR credit as their own when reporting to the higher authorities.
-Very pol

Title: Strong top but weak middle management
Pro: Stable and good worklife balance. CEO very proactive in fixing inefficiencies in the org and pushing for new innovations. Love the "employee journey" initiatives that focus on how to make work easier for employees. MDs i worked with are very knowledgeable with indepth domain knowledge.
Con: Very bureaucratic middle mgt (below MD level) slows down everything. Has reputation of promoting based on length of tenure - have seen dozens of very laid back individuals promoted to svp.

Title: IBG
Pro: Decent staff benefits e.g. share scheme, staff rates for loans etc, company great in marketing itself (best digital bank etc), better off to be a shareholder instead
Con: Annual salary increment is worst than inflation, mgt’s excuses for low bonus and pay increment will be budget not met but you still see the bank achieving record profits and senior mgt getting huge pay raises, layers of bureaucracy to get things done

Title: Deserves only 2 stars 1 for facilities 1 for pay
Pro: Good facilities, cab, encashment for medical expenses
Con: No work life balance, lot of pressure, onsite counterparts say to complete the task by eod however complex it might, no proper management non cooperative managers and leads no team bonding activities, no fun at work, no encourage for sports no proper ETA hurry in deliveries fail in prod lot of rework nature , nothing to learn new worst technically lmplemented projects

Pro: Provides good training class for new employees. Although the learning curve is steep, senior colleagues are all very friendly and willing to teach and guide you along the way. Pay is very attractive compare to other local banks in Singapore. Work culture tend to vary from different branch manager or service manager, but overall they managers try to avoid work politics and lay a healthy work environment. Continuous learning opportunity!
Con: Long working hours. People with difficulty managing time or come out with a suitable daily routine would find themselves wearing out very quickly. Work with an end goal in mind!
